newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finnish Fazer sees cocoa down soon, long-term rise.
newsitem.headline: Finnish Fazer sees cocoa down soon, long-term rise.

text.p: Cocoa prices are likely to ease soon after a recent rally, but will return to their long-term rising trend of about five percent per year, Finnish confectionery group Oy Karl Fazer Ab said on Tuesday.

"Cocoa prices have risen sharply in the last few days, but we believe they will come down again ... we believe that the long-term trend is for a rise of about five percent per year," Fazer Vice President Hans Olof Danielsson told Reuters after a news conference on the group's 1996 results.
"This peak (of recent days) is due to speculation, and for that reason it will also level off," he said.
"Demand has increased in Western Europe," Danielsson said. "The (price) trend is rising, at a rate of about five percent a year."

Danielsson said family-owned Fazer was the Nordic region's second biggest buyer of cocoa after Sweden's Marabou, a unit of Norwegian Freija Marabou Suchard A/S, itself part of Philip Morris Cos Inc of the U.S.
Fazer purchases about 100 million markka worth of cocoa annually, but buys only for its own use and is not involved in speculative trading.
"We have our (cocoa price) risk covered. These fluctuations will not affect our earnings for this year," Danielsson said.
On Monday, London cocoa prices ended higher across the board, rising close to last week's peak of 1,033 stg for the May benchmark, up from a low of 855 stg in mid-February.
New York cocoa prices also rallied sharply on Monday, rising to fresh seven-month highs on chart-driven speculative buying.
